Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Molecular basis for protein sorption in polymer-modified chromatographic media

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Lenhoff / Szleifer
1263966 / 1264696

The goal of the collaborative project is to quantify the functional characteristics of polymer-derivatized media (PDM) to gain an understanding of the mechanism of protein sorption and transport within the matrix using experimental and computational methods. The focus is on ion exchange polymers that allow for both partitioning and surface sorption. The research is organized around three specific aims:

1) Determine comparative sorption and transport characteristics for proteins on PDM with different architectures.
2) Measure microscopic characteristics of the sorption process and the sorbed state as a guide to identification and analysis of sorption and transport mechanisms.
3) Generalize and apply molecular theories to describe the sorption equilibrium and kinetics of proteins in PDM.

The first two aims cover generation of a wide array of experimental data that will make possible a detailed mechanistic analysis of the phenomena involved. These two aims differ in that the first covers chromatographic behavior that is directly meaningful in assessing function under normal process conditions, while the second involves more fine-grained, primarily microscopic methods that are intended to resolve ambiguities regarding possible mechanisms. The third aim will employ realistic, state-of-the art molecular modeling to simulate equilibrium and kinetic behavior of proteins in polymer-derivatized ion-exchange media and provide a rigorous basis for resolving mechanistic uncertainties. Once completed, these studies will allow the development of simpler relationships suitable for routine use in chromatographic modeling, and these methods will then be applied to predicting the efficacy of separation of a model mixture. Successful completion of the investigation will yield structure-function relations that can facilitate explanation of observed performance trends, optimization of materials selection for specific separations, and design of novel adsorbents. Broader impacts. The results of the project are expected to elucidate the mechanisms of actions of PDM and hence benefit research and development in the biotechnology and pharmaceutical industries. The work may help resolve important issues such as slow elution that currently bedevil some applications. For stationary-phase manufacturers, a clearer understanding of the underlying mechanisms of action can guide development of new adsorbents; the PIs have collaborations with relevant companies. While the findings of the research will be disseminated mainly by publication in peer-reviewed journals, the PIs will also make the larger output from the research available to the research community, including software to apply the molecular theory to chromatographic processes. The impact in student training in research will be enriched by the multidisciplinary and multisite collaboration.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Background of project. Protein adsorption plays a central role in diverse industrial applications such as pharmacy, food, biotechnology, and biomedicine. In all such applications the key objective is the purification and separation of a specific protein that has certain biological function or therapeutic activity. For example, purified insulin is used widely in human therapeutics. In order to obtain purified protein one needs to filter and separate the specific sought-after protein from the complex mixture in which it was obtained. The purification of proteins from a complex protein mixture usually involves several separation steps, in which competitive adsorption of multiple different types of proteins is the key occurring phenomenon. Still, competitive adsorption of proteins is a very complex and poorly understood problem. Most of the knowledge of competitive protein adsorption is obtained empirically through trial and error, an approach that is expensive and cumbersome. Thus the ability to develop theoretical models that can predict the process of selective protein adsorption would allow us to optimize the process parameters, enabling us to better design industrial strategies for protein separation.

Summary of the project’s findings. The key project outcomes involve the capability to predict the specific adsorption of a protein or a mixture of proteins as a function of the system parameters. Examples of the system parameters involve the amount of proteins, (concentration), acidity (pH) and concentration of salt molecules of the solution. To that end, we developed a theoretical model to describe the phenomenon of protein adsorption onto a substrate. Our theoretical predictions were tested and validated in a parallel experimental study performed by our collaborators. The molecular theory was capable of describing the key characteristics of protein adsorption for a number of different types of surfaces. In addition, within our theoretical framework we could also study the competitive adsorption of two different types of proteins onto a substrate.

Our calculations showed that when two types of proteins of comparable sizes adsorb onto a charged surface, the protein that will preferentially adsorb (meaning in larger amounts) is the protein that has a greater opposite electric charge with respect to substrate. Most of the empirical understanding of competitive protein adsorption is based on knowledge of the electrical charge state of the protein in solution. However, the amount of electrical charge of each protein and that of the substrate is far from being constant, and is in fact a very complex function of a lot of system variables such as pH, ionic strength, etc. A very important and interesting finding is that when the proteins adsorbed onto the substrate their amount of electric charge was very different than what the protein had in solution. Additionally, the adsorption process can also alter the charge state of the substrate. This phenomenon can lead to counterintuitive results concerning the amount of adsorbed proteins. Thus, understanding the solution behavior of protein’s charge is not enough to explain the observed behavior of protein adsorption, and new concepts and insights are needed. The current work can be seen as an attempt to provide such new insight. Finally, our theoretical predictions were in good qualitative agreement with experimental observations. In summary, our theoretical model provides a platform for a deeper more fundamental understanding of competitive adsorption of proteins. These new insights can translate into rational design guidelines for substrates in applications involving protein adsorption.
